description.text:
A Deadpool-inspired money clip. Includes files for the main body as well as the insert pieces for the logo!

The clip has a cutout where the two sides meet so that it can grip just one credit card or bill.

Check us out at http://makerx.io/ !

Printer:

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Notes:

Recommended settings for a strong clip:

30% infill, 2 shells, 3-4 top/bottom layers, 100 microns.

Print upright with the logo perpendicular to the baseplate so that the clip flexes along the layer grain.

description.text:
I have lots of old Lego road pieces, and the crossings that come with the new Lego train sets aren't wide enough to go across the entire road, so I made this to fit.

I modified barspin's connector design a little bit to make it easier to snap the pieces together (which I needed...you might not).

I also removed the supports at the end of the rails, and let the printer add them. I ran off one in ABS and it turned out great. You can add supports back in if necessary.

description.text:
My father had the idea of using old floppies together with the storage cases to categorize SD cards. I went designing the holder and this is what came out. All holders are pretty much untested or need refinement, but V2 works quite well (V3 hasn't finished printing yet.) V1 and V2 need the extra pocket, but can be printed laying flat. V3 needs to be printed with support material or upside-down like the file provided. Version history: V1: Proof-of-concept, initial version
V2: Modified V1 to use less material and print faster
V3: Redesign to be printable in one piece

V1 and V2: Print Aufsatz_Vx.STL and Einsatz.STL.
Clean up the edges and clip onto the floppy like shown in the picture.
Press-fit the tabs into the write-protect holes.
Press-fit the pocket into the holder.
Insert SD card. V3:
Print Aufsatz_Vx.STL
Press-fit the tabs into the write-protect holes.
Insert SD card.

author: t4a

description.text: This is an ABS fume reducer built to plug in to the MK6+ extruder frame. The MK6+ extruder frame forms a natural "vent hood" when you block off the sides with clear tape. This filter reduces the ABS fumes by around 80%-90%. The hood seems to be very efficient at picking up the abs fumes, but some of the fumes make their way through the filter due to the coarse nature of charcoal filter that was used. The tubing used is sold by the yard from a big-box home improvement place and is between 30-31mm in diameter at the narrower "plug-in portion".

Warning! The filter holder and tube connector are both at or slightly larger than the print size limits of the TOM. In order to print these, I had to sand out divots and square out the lower corners in the front frame of the TOM so that bolts at the front of the ABP and the lower corner of the ABP would not hit the frame (see the divots taken out of the frame in the second image). You can insure that your adjustments are working by manually moving your build platform such that its acrylic sides are just brushing against the TOM front frame (the bolts on the left and right sides of the ABP should not contact the TOM frame). It is also important to re-calibrate your TOM before printing these to insure you are operating from the exact center of the print surface. The 12V fan used is about 91.5mm square and was recycled from an old PC. The fan is powered from an unused TOM 12V power supply connector (the connector with the black/yellow wires is 12V where yellow=+ and black=-). The charcoal filter is 3 layers of litterbox filter from a pet store. The gen2 version of this thing will include a different filter medium with a finer grain. The vent-hood design will remain the same. You can see the second generation version of this filter here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18483

description.text: I modified the back of thing:302862 to attach to a floating support made by modelatolyesi (thing:397716)

ssd-spacer goes between an SSD and the side of a 3.5" server drive caddy. The advantage of this design is that it does not place a 1 or 2 mm layer of plastic under or next to the SSD. This allows the SATA connector to remain aligned in the bottom right hand corner of the drive bay.

This project is in mostly stable. Prototypes have been printed and tested in the real world. Measurements are very accurate, but some filing of screw holes is necessary.

When using the Lulzbot's recommended profile for Cura, which sets the layer height to 0.25 mm, a Lulzbot Mini printed this object in about an hour.

ssd-spacer is designed with ImplicitCAD.

Parts Needed

You will need one or two metal files, one capable of trimming the bottom edge and a round pointy one to fit inside of small screw holes.

Source Code
  • git repository

Cleaning the Edges

If the bottom layers are wider than the middle and top layers, use a metal file to file down the long bottom edges that will be in contact with the side of the SSD and caddy. Smooth out any rough edges created by filing to avoid blowing plastic bits into your server.

Caddy Screw Issues

Before screwing the SSD, spacer and caddy together, try screwing the caddy screws directly into the corresponding screw holes. You may not be able to do this until you slightly increase hole size. When the holes are a proper size it should still require considerable strength and a large-handled screw driver to screw them in for the first time.

Do not make the holes too big unless you wish to use a nut. Otherwise the screw threads will not grip the plastic well and may fall out.

  • One way to increase the size of the screw holes is by carefully filing the plastic with a pointy metal file.

  • You may also wish to increase the hole size, specified as caddyScrewRadius in the .escad file by about 0.05 - 0.2 mm. (I am not off by a factor of 10.) This may require experimentation and extra printing. Correct sizes may vary according to the model of printer used. Using a metal file should require less guesswork than this method.

  • Another option is to put a nut on the end of a longer screw. The screw head should be on the small size so the caddy will fit into the drive bay. If you go this route, you may wish to dramatically increase the diameter of these holes (caddyScrewRadius). You may also wish to increase the radius of the nut space to fit a larger nut (caddyNutSpaceRadius).

The SSD holes do not pose this problem as the threads lie inside the SSD, not the plastic.

Other Caveats

Frequent screwing and unscrewing of the caddy screws may strip out the threads dug into the plastic created by the first screwing. If you gently turn the screw with mild pressure as it begins to fit into the old thread pattern, you may increase the life of the part.

I created this in ImplicitCAD and used blender to view .stl file as I made changes.

Each ssd screw head and screw access space are created by a single sigmoidal extrustion.

print_settings.Notes:: ..........sorry, the cool formatting is from the program, not from me.

description.text:
this is the pioneer wagon from here:
https://www.cgtrader.com/3d-print-models/miniatures/vehicles/pioneer-wagon

as usual, my printer has problems to print complicated forms (specially standing wheels)
so, for printing this wagon i just cut it up with netfabb.

the wheels and the drawbars should print without support, the other parts need support.

the thing is scaled in 1:32ish ;-)

Printer:

daVinci AiO

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

btw, for those, who have the same ever returning problem as i have - scaling!

to change scale, just divide the actual scale, through the scale you want.
-so let's say, a tall person has a height of 6' or 180 cm.
-in 1:32 that would be a figure of 5.6cm or 56mm height. (180cm:32)
-in G-scale/ 1:22.5 the figure should be a figure of 8cm or 80mm.
-let's make the test: 80mm divided by 56mm is? right. 1.41 (or 141% of 56mm)

...so, for F scale or 1:20.3 you print the wagon in 158%.
...for G scale or 1:22.5 in 142%
...for 1:24 in 133%
...for 1:25 in 128%
...in 1:29 in 110%
...in 1:32 in 100%
...in 1:35 in 91%
...in 1:48 in 67%
...in 28mm scale at 50%
...in H0 or 1:87 at 37%
...in 18mm scale at 32%
...in N scale? forgeddit!

..........sorry, the cool formatting is from the program, not from me.

if you want a model, just glue the parts together and paint them.

if you want it to move:
find some screws from a broken plastic toy or radio,
drill a hole in the hub/center of the wheels, in a diameter, that one can push the screw in, without turning it.
take the next smaller drill, and make holes in the axles.

i think, i'll search for some oxen to draw that wagon.

edit 2016, april 15
printed it with 0.2 layers, slow print and "excellent" quality. the supports on medium density setting. each part alone.

it took about 21 hours of total printing time.

title: Mod to enable Up!/Afina to print Ninjaflex

description.text:
This is a simple printed block that replaces the bearing tensioner with a 4mm/2mm OD/ID PTFE tube cut to make room for the extruder gear.

Chamfer the end of the tubing with a sharp exacto blade such that you can push your hot end up for a gapless seal between the PTFE and the metal tube.

Push your PTFE tubing through the block from the top of the assembly until the full chamfered portion sticks out below the printed block (Afinia printers will need special care to ensure that your hot end is able to push against the PTFE and fully seat into its heat sink, check this before you make the extruder gear cut).

Cut a window to make room for the extruder gear. The bottom of the cut should be as close to the OD of the gear as possible, the top can be sloppy and leaving a wide gap is not a problem.

While this mod (after my second cutting of the tubing) kept the filament from buckling before it got to the nozzle, it did stop printing after a few minutes at 240 degrees or colder. At 250 I have gotten two successful prints and no failures. Parts look good.

While I have not tried to print ABS or PLA with this setup, I have doubts that that will work due to the highly constrained filament path. Loosening up the path and using a screw to tension the PTFE directly across from the gear may give you the ability to print hard and soft materials without having to swap back to your standard extruder setup.

I found mordiev's project (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001060) helpful in making this thing.

DrewPetitclerc's project (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16711) and feedback helped a great deal in getting this done.

Printer Brand:

Afinia

Printer:

AFINIA H480

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

high

Notes:

Used Z-Ultrat filament for strength and low warp.

To print Ninjaflex I used fixup3d (https://github.com/ForsakenNGS/FixUp3D) with the following settings:

Heater Temp. Layer 1 250, Layer 2 250, Layer 3 250
Set 2 (layer thickness 0.25)
Scan Speed 25
Hatch Speed 25
Support Speed 25
All other values left at their default.

3/4/16: While I got two good prints out of this yesterday the same setup today is skipping a couple times then extruding, skipping then extruding, leaving my part printed but at only about half the density of the parts I made yesterday. Have tweaked the scan speed to 15 on all three of the values above, hoping this print comes out complete.

3/15/16: Working with the above settings. My prints have been small gaskets. Please share if you make this work for you for small or large parts.

Change the spacing between your hot end and your extruder motor.

For the filament path to go directly into the top of the hot end you will need to space out your hot end/heat sink from the extruder motor. See photo showing 1mm washers left and right and in the middle where the top of the hot end is held in place (middle washer is on top of two spacers I need to keep the hot end tightly captured).

Be careful not to strip your holes out, you have 1mm less thread engagement. I stripped one of mine and had to get a longer 3mm screw to engage deeper in the hole.
Designed in Solidworks 2015

comments.text: You guys are so far advanced.  I'd like to just be able to print run-of-the-mill PLA from my Up Plus 2.   Recreus doesn't seem to sell the afinia version of their hot end, which seems like a requirement :(
comments.author: Horganic

comments.text: PLA was a struggle for me, too. After finding the Hatchbox brand, I've had no problem PLA. Some others work but not nearly as consistently as Hatchbox which prints well at the default temp (~205 degrees). Only issue with Hatchbox I've had is it going out of stock on Amazon which I just came up against last night looking to get another roll of their translucent orange. I mostly print black and it never fails me (knock on wood).
comments.author: Horganic

comments.text:
Nice work, watch for wear of the tube from the filament constantly sliding by, look at the trough made in the face of the stepper motor where the plastic wears a path over time.
But nice approach to the issue!
comments.author: DrewPetitclerc

comments.text: That means a lot coming from you, Drew. Since we rarely need Ninjaflex I expect to take this off after half a dozen prints or so and go back to my ball bearing tensioned setup or, better yet, break out the mill and implement your bearing tensioned setup. I'll take a look at what the wear is on the tubing and gear teeth.
comments.author: DrewPetitclerc

title: MK2 heated bed glass corner holder

description.text:
The clamps i bought for the glass is too ugly, and it looks unprofessional. spent an hour trying to look for alternative online with no luck, so i have decided to design one myself. Detail:
heated bed: MK2 from prusa mendel i2 kit(mixshop)
glass: 7 3/4" square x 3mm thick
corner hole diameter: 3mm one of my concern was that since the part is made of PLA, i was worried that it might warp/deform as it has direct contact to the heated bed. printed a few things and been working great so far. although the glass thickness is 3mm, i made the counterpart 2.8mm so it can be tightened. note that this only works if your glass size is exactly the same as mine 7 3/4" or 196.8mm, haven't really looked into the parametric function on this site. But i will do it upon request

title: Prusa i3v - X Carriage - Direct Drive V2

description.text:
V2 of my original X carriage - still WIP for testing.

I recently switched to an inductive sensor instead of my old capacitive one for ABL. The inductive sensor has a smaller detection range and my older V1 design had the probe mount too high to be used. I also wanted to change a few aesthetics of the design and try to create it all from scratch. This version is the result of those efforts.

author: Adolph

description.text: I just got a 3D printer and this is my very first edit. I bought it to supply parts for my racing quadcopter hobby. I printed the GoPro mount by JJBTEXAS which worked great to adapt it to my GoPro gear, but I wanted to make a mount for my quads so I wouldn't have to risk my GoPro. So I just edited out the base and added a 20 degree mount with slots for zip ties. The first print was pretty good, but I printed it upside down and the base at the top sagged a little in one spot, but the cube still fits.

print_settings.Notes:: Supports are needed for printing the body.  They are not required for the button.

title: Emergency Stop Button for Stanley Power Strip

description.text:
I made this emergency stop button for my MPCNC. It's used with a Stanley Power Strip. The printed body slides over the on/off button of the power strip. The red button is placed in the printed body. When the red button is pressed, it presses on the off side of the on/off button and kills power to the power strip. Here is a video of the stop button's operation:

https://youtu.be/9Gde6d5Ogbc

I have included the 123D file if you wish to modify this for another power strip.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

60%

Notes:

Supports are needed for printing the body. They are not required for the button.

The support material needs to be cleaned out of the hole in the base so the button slides freely in the hole. Test fit the parts before using. Test the button to make sure it is on the correct direction to turn off the switch.

If your using a different power strip, or it doesn't fit correctly, I have included the D123 file that you can edit.

description.text: This is a 'kit' for designing or building magic screw threads that will (hopefully) build on a Thing-o-Matic and similar hobby printers. This should enable you to build a bolt and nuts so that one nut tightens normally while the other seems to turn the wrong way as shown in this video (this is the new model data): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gx_OKYA3_Iw The ancestor model did not build accurately on hobby-type 3D printers because (I think) the geometry had atypical overhangs that could foreseeably flatten out during extrusion. Instead of fighting those overhangs, this Magic Screw version tries to exploit them by building overhangs in straight lines between supported walls. It's just a conjecture (I don't know if I'm right) but it's illustrated in my blog at http://mysd300.blogspot.com/2011/12/magic-screw-for-makerbots.html

Try building the three STL files as-is and see if they'll work exactly like the video. If the model needs tweaking, or if you'd like to optimize the appearance of the trick threads, download and edit bwbolt.scad using OpenSCAD. Follow the instructions (comments) for some simple adjustments, or revise the whole thread profile as desired. Be sure to share a derivative if you get a model that works better or looks better!

comments.text: I easily rotated the bolt in Simplify3D Creator. I accidentally printed this out with supports. Luckily, it didn't produce too many blocks, and I was able to cleanly remove them. Great! Fits absolutely perfect. My only request would be that the bolt be longer so that there is more play area to work with.
comments.author: jmccorm

comments.text: Edit the SCAD file and make yourself a derivative!  You could make the bolt as long as you like.  While you're at it, try to improve its appearance or build-ability.  I don't own a Makerbot, and my SD300 printer is immune to overhang issues, so I can't do any more tuning for Makerbot users.
comments.author: jmccorm

comments.text: Printed perfectly on my Tantillus RepRap printer. :)
comments.author: robots-dreams

comments.text: Working fine! Thanks.
comments.author: Fuzzylogic

comments.text: Printed the bolt in Faberdashery Crystal Clear PLA - no problem at all and did not require any additional cooling (which I was expecting owing to the small layer surface area as the thread builds up). The forward nut - printed in Electric Blue equally as good and both bolt and nut worked exactly as they should - smooth yet tight when the nut got to the bolt head. However .... the backwards nut in Fire Engine Red has come out rather loose. I can wiggle it up and down the bolt with a little bit of twisting - which is a shame as this was shaping up to be a first time win thing.  (When this nut gets to the bolt head it just swivels around - cannot tighten it). Not a clue what parameters to change otherwise I would have another go at printing the backward nut. I am using a RepRapPro Huxley by the way.
comments.author: Alzibiff

comments.text: Tried printing with bwd_off at 1.2 and this time I couldn't get the backward nut on the bolt .... basically not a clue what I'm doing! Anyone else got some settings to share?
comments.author: Alzibiff

comments.text: The larger thread nut was a bit tight and the smaller thread nut was a bit loose, but both work (in opposite directions) on the bolt.  Printed on a Thing-O-Matic MK7 HBP 220C/110C with a .35mm layer height.
comments.author: SamCo

comments.text: Correction to an earlier comment... I printed this on an Orca from PLA with 0.20 layer height and the results were... odd. The threads on the bolt look good, but what happened was that the backwards nut would go in forwards. with just a little fiddling around. Forwards nut would refuse to go in at all and when I printed it with increased tolerance (tol = 0.3 in SCAD file), it would go in backwards (using quite a bit of force...)! Spooky!
comments.author: ttsalo

comments.text: Here we go again ;-)

description.text:
A mount for the GoPro Session with some angle and vibration dampening if printed with a flexible filament.
Designed for the beautiful Quadrysteria QR200, but will work on other quads, too.

Printer:

TinyBoy

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Please use some support for the bottom part.
Print with very low infill, I chose 20%, and a flexible filament to make this bumper soft and rubbery. I had good results with Ninjaflex Semiflex, but others will work, too.

comments.text:
Hello, I was curious to know if I could ask you for a design change. I am willing to pay you for it.
I would like to install this camera on the QR-200 but I would like to do away with the carbon fiber camera pod altogether.
The idea would be to replace the camera pod with this. Possibly by using the two horizontal standoffs on the base of the 3D printed mount?
Let me know if this is at all possible. Thank you!
comments.author: bismaxx

comments.text:
Hi, I made a similar mount for my polaroid cube+ and it works great:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1443497
Sadly the session is bigger then the cube, so it won't fit :/
I could design one for the session but not for money. If you ship me a gopro session, I'll make a nice mount, print it and send it to you.
comments.author: bismaxx

comments.text:
Do you keep the camera as compensation? Not sure if that's what you mean? Lol
I wouldn't want you to do it for free. Specially if you are printing it.
comments.author: AdamPyschny

comments.text: Yes, I'd keep the cam as compensation. Designing such a mount is about one weekend of work, or ~10-12hours strictly net without waiting for testprints and fitting.
comments.author: bismaxx

comments.text: I see. Unfortunately I can't pay you with the camera and the cost of the camera seems pretty steep for what it is ($200). We could negotiate a PayPal payment. But I understand if it's not worth your while.
comments.author: AdamPyschny

comments.text:
Main problem is that I don't own a session any more. I switched to the cubes because of weight and size. Constructing blindly leads to suboptimal results because if will not fit perfectly :/
I learned CAD by simply fiddling with tinkercad for a while and switching to freecad afterwards. You should try it out, its a great skill and not that hard to learn. especially tinkercad is great for beginners because it offers a tutorial where you learn all basics step by step.
comments.author: bismaxx

comments.text:
Sending you the Session would not be an issue as long as I get it back. That's all.
I have a degree in CAD, and for many years did 3D modeling with Autodesk products, Vector Works, Rhyno, and 3D studio before I left that industry. So I don't think it would be difficult to design. But in order to get this right I would need a printer at home with the right filament in order to prototype and get everything right, and that I don't have ATM.
Designing this shouldn't be strenuous work. you already designed an awesome mount for the cube that does away with the QR-200 Camera Pod, and you have a model for the Session as well. So now its just a matter of matching the bottom of the cube mount with the upper part of the Session mount. Most of the actual design and measuring is already done by you. And for that we thank you.

author: jstovermcs

title: nun on the run beer tap handle

description.text:
My brother is building a bar in his basement and he wanted to have a "Luther" theme to it. He asked me if it was possible to 3d print tap handles. 'Ha child's play' I responded. So I'm working on Martin Luther themed tap handles.

This model is called 'Nun on the Run' Luther's wife Katie, was a nun who through Luther's writings became evangelical, she wanted to leave the convent, but it was against canon law and she could have been arrested so in order to escape she hid in a barrel of herring, as the story is told, and made her way out of the convent and eventually to Luther himself. She was an amazing lady and worthy of having her own beer/tap handle. Katie herself was an avid brewer, making all of Luther's beer and actually selling it as well.

Barrel comes with a threaded hole for easy installation.

Thanks to the wife for help with the painting.

Timelapse: https://youtu.be/DUeeh1BHiV0

I designed this wall mount pc case because i was bored with PC cases, allot look really cool but i find that wall mounted PCs look really cool.

This design is rough, The mounting holes for the motherboard are as accurate as the dimensions I found online. Mounting for the graphics card and power supply will have to be done by whoever makes it...For the SSDs just double sided sponge tape would d nicely. Also, the legs, these are half inch carbon tube...the length at which they should be cut will depend on you CPU cooling and/or power supply.

Making - If you do make it, then it will need to be made on a CNC router. Using 10mm thick board,plastic or metal... I think Aluminium would look pretty sick.

Hope you like it! and Please Subscribe to my Youtube Channel where ill be adding other things, more quadcopter related...and 3D printing friendly :)

title: Linear Bearing Mount for LM12LUU 12mm rod diameter

description.text:
This is my first attempt at modeling something useful.
The LM12LUU linear bearings came without a mount when I bought them online, I decided to make one, after a few attempts, this is what I came up with.

The measurements are:
Bearing length = 57mm
Bearing outer diameter = 21mm
Bearing inner diameter (not relevant for this part) = 12mm
All screw holes diameter = 3mm

The screw holes are 3mm, I found out that I could use the bracket holes that keep the part closed without a nut on the other end just by threading the screw into the hole.
It might not be the strongest option, so I might end up modifying it to add a hole on the other side for a captive nut.
Feel free to do so yourself! ;)

This is the spaceship Star Ranger from the Starman book series (amazon link). The ship is main spaceship in the stories and appears on the cover of the 5th book, A Kingdom in Twilight (originally titled The Lost Race of Mars).

This model is 6 inches tall, although the one in the picture is 9 inches (scaled to 150%). I didn't think it would print well as one piece, so I chopped it off at the nose to give flat surfaces. The ship is bright red in the books, so I printed it with true red.

There is also a custom stand for this ship with the name and logo on it here.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.23mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Scaled to 150% because it is more impressive looking.
The nozzles (x3) were too fine to print as part of the main ship, so they are separate parts.
Have never tried to print the ship as one piece, so don't know how it would turn out.

The artist for some of the books (Bill Baumann) made sketches of the ship from the top, side and front and one of the authors was kind enough to send them to me. I used these as background images in blender and traced the outlines to get the basic shape. From there I did a lot of smoothing, etc.

The books indicate that there are nozzles on the back, but they aren't visible in any of the drawings, so I made an indentation in the back and slapped in three (slightly modified) Saturn V rocket nozzles.

comments.text: This model is also available from me on shapeways (very nice prints, but expensive) and redpah.

title: 5.5 inch Table for FreeLSS Scanner using 28byj-48 stepper

description.text:
I opted not to use a NEMA 17 stepper for my FreeLSS scanner project due to the fact that I have several of the 28byj-48 stepper laying around. The 28byj-48's can be converted to a bipolar using these instructions written by Jangeox @

http://www.jangeox.be/2013/10/change-unipolar-28byj-48-to-bipolar.html

Once the conversion to a Bi-Polar is complete, a A4988 stepper driver can drive these motors quite well. Thus making it possible to use them with the original FreeLSS design.

And a Thanks to Jangeox for his contribution. I simply merged 2 thing files, the 5p5 table from the Freelss STL's, and this pulley from Vertical Mirobot by aut0mata (1017109). The table is on the printer now, I will update this post when it is complete.

Have you ever wanted a computer in your pocket serving up music both streaming and via FM, hosting up file sharing, offering secure VOIP and chat as well as secure shell services? Yes, you do, you really really do. I can tell.
Now you can.
I have been working on this project for a while and it was recently morphed for a Hackaday Contest . https://hackaday.io/project/9498-pifold This setup uses a PiZero, a lipo battery, an Adadfruit Powerboot and a USB Wifi dongle to do all the things mentioned above. My first take on it was housed in a Tyvek Wallet. It does work great but some have asked for a more secure case to both house it in and to have an opening for easy charging.
I found this fantastic wallet here on Thingiverse, The Planet Mike had already crafted up the very idea I wanted in a pocket sized case even before I knew I wanted it. Much thanks Mike.
The only modification I have made to his stl was to increase the depth of the wallet so it would fit all the parts with a little wiglle room. It still has all the great feature but for some pockets it might be a tight fit. For backpacks, purses, cargo pants and coat jackets it will be a perfect fit.
Once set up you will have an amazing cloud of resources surrounding you, binding you, etc etc etc. Recharge at night for use during the day. I have even included the plans to build up an optional solar panel charging unit.
As time goes on I will be tweaking and updating things to make the set up even better. Enjoy.

print_settings.Notes:: scaled-up 2X

description.text:
The idea for this came from Thing 11977, although the design is all new.

Basically, it's an apparently impossible dovetail joint that opens by rotating. My interesting little observation was that it needs almost no thickness, and no core, in order to lock and rotate well. It's a tiny empty box. As a result, this prints in a few minutes on our MakerGear M2 -- it prints better and nicer scaled-up 2X.

There are two versions here as STL files: one with the new University of Kentucky logo on one side and our department name (ECE) on the other, and a second plain version. The logo one was made in quantity and handed-out to EDay Open House visitors to our lab; interestingly, we had no problems fitting pieces together that were made on either of two MakerGear M2 and one Wanhao I3.

title: Water Rocket (Bottle Rocket) Adapter With Giant Fins

description.text:
This is a derivative of my 2 Liter bottle to 1/4 NPT adapter with giant Tom Swift style fins. The adapter is designed to let you quickly turn an ordinary house hold pop (soda) bottle into a projectile by adding water and air pressure. the 1/4 NPT quick disconnect gives you a simple and easy way to add air pressure and also works as a launch mechanism when you release the collar.
In all honesty this is a bit impractical as the fins are huge and brittle and the purpose of this object is to be launched sky high and fall back uncontrolled to smash into the ground, but I had to print one up, what's life without whimsy?

Please see the parent of this item for instructions, that way I can just make corrections there as I intend to make several derivatives.
The "rendering" of this thing makes it look like it's just the fins, I was able to print one out without a problem, I'm wondering if my uploaded file got corrupted or it is just rendering wrong. I would appreciate it if anyone finds there is something wrong with the file they would let me know so I can fix it.

description.text:
Check out my YouTube Channel at https://www.youtube.com/user/JBFromOZ

Tramming the cutting head of a Mill to the table can be a time consuming task, and one that involves a lot of contortion to look through the back of a single dial gauge.
By using two "like" gauges, in a beam, a single point is used as a start point reference, setting both indicators reading the same at that point.
Once both indicators measure the same height at the same point, the beam is turned along or across the table to measure the offset from vertical of the mill head.
adjustment is made as appropriate to bring both dials to read the same value, and levelling the head.
In some cases using a larger diameter fly cutter, the leading edge of the fly cutting is desired to be fractionally lower than the trailing edge, to eliminate back cutting on the return path across the work.
This can be seen in the second picture where the left/right alignment shows the left side half a thousandth lower, and the right side shows half a thousandth higher.
a couple of M3 cap head bolts and nuts are required to finish the item.

Printer:

TrinityLabs Aluminatus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm layer heights

Infill:

20%

drawn up in OpenSCAD to suit measured diameter of the two gauges I had on hand.
Parametric design used so that you can set up as you require.

the outer pair of holes is for the widest part of the mill bed, next set to tram up our 6 inch vice, and the closest pair to tram up our smallest vice.

The Creality 3D printer is a clone of Deezmaker's excellent Bukito 3D printer (which I also own one of). While the Creality improves upon the Bukito by providing an LCD interface, it is mechanically inferior in several ways

  1. The vertical tower in the Creality is held to a horizontal extrusion by a very small corner bracket. There's little to prevent the tower from twisting forward. The Z stepper motor helps to resist twisting backwards. The Bukito firmly secures the vertical tower in two perpendicular planes to the custom bottom plate.
  2. The belt paths are not kept in the same plane as the motion of the X and Y carriages.
  3. The X and Y idler supports in the Creality are not adequately stiff and introduce additional ringing, albeit negligible at low printing speeds.
  4. The Creality's hot end uses a PTFE liner all the way to the hot nozzle. The PTFE will degrade over time and require replacement. Further, this limits the printing temps which can be used to below 240C. It further limits maximum printing speeds as only so much heat can be provided via the reduced melt chamber size.
  5. The Creality's pinch gear doesn't have sufficient bite in hard PLA and slips occasionally.

While not a mechanical defect, the Creality lacks a print cooling fan. As the Creality is clearly intended for printing PLA (and comes with a sample of PLA filament), lack of a print cooling fan is a significant omission. Particularly since you need one for small prints and the Creality is otherwise best suited to small prints.

In this Thing, I provide some modifications which may be used to help address these issues.

After you read the amount of modifications and parts changes I made, you may well ask yourself whether this was any less expensive than buying a Bukito kit. Just the electronics alone which I used cost about $240 US not including shipping ($206 for Duet 0.8.5 + Panel Due; another $35 for a larger power supply). I further used at least another $160 in parts and possibly closer to $200 (four stepper motors, heated bed, Neutrik 20A power inlet, E3Dv6 hot end parts, extruder parts, etc.). And that's not counting any shipping costs. So, all in all, it was perhaps a wash when compared to the cost of a Bukito kit. On the other hand, in the end I ended up with a heated bed and a touch screen interface neither of which you get with a Bukito or Creality.

As an aside do not believe the Creality claim of "1 hour assembly time". I figure it will take most people more than five hours.

A few additional photos at Flickr.
Click here for a video of the uncalibrated printer's first print.

0 Must do

  1. The vertical tower must have a more secure mounting mechanism. Below I recommend using an L-plate which you must source (e.g., Adafruit).
  2. For printing with PLA, particularly small parts, you need a print cooling fan. While you can just point a fan at the printer, having one mounted on the hot end and controlled via print instructions is far more convenient. You will need a means of mounting a fan as well as sourcing a 12V DC fan (or a 24V fan if you convert your system to that voltage).
  3. Inspect your initial prints looking for any signs of the pinch gear slipping (little gaps in the exterior). If you see these signs, then you can try using a stronger spring in the extruder or source a pinch gear with a more aggressive bite or both.
  4. Check out the kit's 12V power supply with a volt meter. Mine, even under load, liked to wander between 8.4 to 11.8V. That's not a good sign. And the power supply had NO certifications. (It did, however, have the "China Export" mark which appears designed to look similar to the European CE mark. See this news article.)

1 Hot end

I removed the oversized metal hot end enclosure and replaced it with a more compact enclosure, the hot_end_fan_shroud.stl which is a download of this Thing. It accepts a 30x30mm fan. I used my own shroud both to open up the underside of the hot end as well as to provide a mount for a cooling fan.

For a cooling fan duct, I used Deezmaker's Bukito PLA cooling fan duct (25 Dec 2016: link is now broken; STL now included with other parts for this Thing): scale it up to fit the size of fan you wish to use. It mounts to the above shroud using two M3 nuts and bolts in the slot on the hot_end_fan_shroud.stl. With the slot, you can adjust the height of the cooling fan. By use of a spacer with the lower mounting bolt, you can also adjust the angle of the fan.

To convert the hot end to an "all metal" hot end, I used an E3Dv6 hot block and 0.4mm nozzle. To feed into the hot block I used a maker-bot style M6 threaded thermal barrier tube, available from Carl Raffle, Micro Swiss, or Performance 3-D. All three of those manufacturers make correct thermal barrier tubes with the slight widening of the inside diameter below the thermal break. Note further that you should use an E3Dv6 nozzle with the E3Dv6 hot block: that hot block is a little thicker than most and the E3Dv6 nozzle has a slightly longer threaded neck as well. This prevents having to thread the thermal barrier tube so far down into the hot block that the hot break is partially embedded.

2 Extruder

I found that the provided brass pinch gear did not have sufficient bite in hard PLA. Prints were showing occasional gaps from where the pinch gear would slip. I replaced the pinch gear and bearing arm with a more aggressive pinch gear (Deezmaker Tatsu). My change necessitated changing the bearing in the lever arm to a flat-faced bearing. I also had to modify the drive block a bit to accomodate the larger diameter pinch gear. (Owing to the trough machined into the gear, the filament still exited at the correct position to reach the exit hole in the feed block.) I used parts I had on hand. Just be aware of the fact that you too may want to replace the pinch gear with something more aggressive.

3 Idler supports

I printed idler supports which would support the idler axles on both ends. This makes the idlers a little stiffer and less prone to bending inward when the X or Y carriages are accelerating away from the idler. That, in turn, reduces vibrations and ringing. The idler support for the X axis is extruder_idler_support.stl. It is thinner on one side so as to allow the extruder carriage to pass over it. Use a low profile M3 bolt as well. The printed parts have interior room for normal extrusion stopper nuts. (I use Misumi's post assembly stopper nuts.) The holes in the parts are intended for a long M3 bolt as the axle. You can change the OpenSCAD sources for a larger bolt. I still used the M8 bearings provided by Creality but inserted some M8 to M3 bushings (e.g., McMaster-Carr aluminum unthreaded spacers).

And yes, you can use extruder_idler_support.stl in for both axes and not just the X axis.

4 Vertical tower

To better support the vertical tower, I added an L-plate bolted to both the vertical tower and horizontal member. Sinking two M4 bolts through the bottom plate into the bottom of the tower might also be a good idea, but it didn't occur to me until it was too late to do so without a fair amount of effort. Adafruit and others sell L-plates for 20x20 extrusions.

I also used a much larger corner bracket than the one provided in the kit. You can get them as well from Adafruit or other suppliers.

5 Drag chain

Since I added a heated build plate, I installed a drag chain as well (10x12mm outside dimensions; 7x7mm inside). Use the drag_chain_mount.stl to print a mount which bolts onto the end of the long, horizontal extrusion.

6 Power inlet

To handle the 15A+ of a heated bed, I installed a 20A Neutrik jack. This works well with Things 441081 (12V) and 1241088 (24V).

7 Electronics

I replaced all the electronics with 64bit ARM electronics using a Duet 0.8.5. That provided nicer electronics, heated bed support, and a very nice web interface. The Duet electronocs and firmware, RepRapFirmware, have an excellent safety record. And they provide a very slick built-in web interface. For an LCD touch screen interface, I added a PanelDue as well. (However, I still need to mount it.) And, frankly, I don't trust the no-name Asian clone electronics. I've seen a few too many go up in smoke. So, I knew from the get go that I would not be using the original Creality electronics.

8 Heated bed

I rebuilt the platform into a 120x120 mm sized platform so that I could use a 12V Thing-o-Matic heated bed. See, e.g., Thing 16958. However, I later changed to a 24V system and used a silicone 24V heater from McMaster-Carr. I made the change from 12 to 24V as it's generally my experience that the stepper motors perform better. Having to deal with less current is an added benefit.

The pictured build plate is a 120x120 mm Zebra plate from Print in Z

9 Stepper motors

First, the Z threaded rod ends up spaced about 1 - 2mm farther away from the vertical tower than the Z stepper motor's shaft. To put them in better alignment, I spaced my Z stepper motor away from the vertical tower by about 1.8mm using two fender washers.

The Creality printer kit came with stepper motors which lacked any identification and specifications. I'm not keen on using stepper motors for which I do not have the specifications. As I have plenty of inexpensive, quality, known-to-be-good-for-3D-printing stepper motors, I used them in place of those which came with the kit. (Namely, Kysan 1124090 stepper motors from Ultimachine.)

The goal of this creation is to place the ToM APB (Automated Build Platform) belt under high tension, so it acts much like a solid plate surface (emulating the HBP (Heated Build Platform) surface) while retaining the ejection capabilities of the APB. This is a lever arm that stretches out your APB belt. Under high tension, the belt resists flexing up at sides due to warping stresses during cooling and sits flat on the heating board before printing. The arm attaches to the sides of the roller bar, and friction is kept to a minimum by bearings at the point of contact. The lever arm tension is set by manipulating a screw.
This bolts onto the stock APB, requiring only two bearings and two short m3 screws to be purchased. Misc M3 screws will allow this to be bolted onto the ABP. However, proper-length countersunk head 10mm to 15mm M3 screws should be used for the tension-setting screws in order to avoid their sticking out and running into the z-stage bars during homing and printing. I recommend using a sturdy belt to handle high tension (such as Tunell's Steel Conveyor Belt for ABP. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9127). Using this tensioner and a kapton-covered steel APB belt, I have been able to achieve quality near that of the Kapton-covered Aluminum HBP while preserving the ability to queue up multiple parts and remotely print. It's not perfect, but I'd say it's pretty darn good.

1) Print & Clean up parts
-I suggest more than zero shells, higher infill levels, as this must be sturdy. 2) Assemble:
-Place bearings into lever arm,
-Place m3 nut into lever arm,
-Partially screw in the 10-15mm, countersunk M3 tensioner screw 3) Put it on the ABP
-Remove the ABP from printer
-Remove existing side screws, bolt on the backing bars, making note of where the X axis endstop should fit.
-Remove APB screw on the lower back (and do not bolt on the lever arm yet!)
-Place lever arm onto the roller bar (roller bar into the bearing), THEN -Bolt in the lever arm pivot point.
-Repeat for other side.
-Put ABP back onto ToM (I suggest sir MakeaLot's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9420 for easy build platform snap-on-snap-off's) 4) Tensioning the belt
-Finger tighten each tension screw until it can no longer further tightened.
-Screw each side in equally... keep tensioning until it is difficult to -Put a fingernail between the belt and the heating board.
-Run the ABP motor to see that you haven't put on too much tension (should still turn belt)
-Wait and see that the belt doesn't drift to one side. (further tighten the side that it drifts towards, if there is drift) 5) Check freedom of movement
-check that the end axis fits and triggers normally.
-check that the screw right before the end axis passes under the backing bar properly.
-check that the tensioner screws don't run into the Z-Stage bars. 6) Be Happy, Queue, Print Remotely, and try to convince people that ABP doesn't suck... it just needs a few modifications.

title: iPhone 6/6+ leather case slide-in shelf/wall pocket

description.text:
need to nest your iPhone 6/6+ easily and without removing it from the original leather case overnight with display facing down e.g. under shelf in your bedroom (e.g. to watch your favorite Red Dwarf episode before you fall asleep)? ... or a pocket on the wall next to your beds to slide in your iPhone in landscape mode?

this is solution tested on my iPhone ;) ... no big magic but very efficient and clean. designed and real life tested ... may evolve a bit in the future but works just fine as it is right now.

when printed on 100% scale from PLA, it will be just big enough to slide in the iPhone 6/6+ with the original Apple leather case on - with very small clearance. If you want more loose fit, just scale 102%in Z axis (height) and 101% in X axis (width) - but not necessary

title: Print your own PCB - PROOF OF CONCEPT

description.text:
This is a PROOF OF CONCEPT how to make your own "PCB" for THT components.
It's just to show that it's possible to make a very crude "PCB" with a 3D printer.
With some modification it is possible to add some of the larger SMD components.

I love electronics, but i don't know how to etch my own PCBs and for my little projects I wanted to have something of my own. That's why i wanted to see if the idea of a 3D printed variation of a PCB is applicaple with a standard 3D printer.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QikAQDyuIuU&feature=youtu.be

Printer:

DIY Mendel90 (Nevex)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

13% Honeycomb

Idea

I love electronics, but i don't know how to etch my own PCBs and for my little projects I wanted to have something of my own. That's why i wanted to see if the idea to 3D print a variation of a PCB is applicaple with a 3D printer.

Concept

To make the idea into practice I wanted to start with a simple circuit: battery, LED and resistor.
I placed the components as in the schematic and started drawing my test "PCB" in SolidWorks.

Test circuit First Design

I thought about how PCBs are made and so i thought about having all the connections on the lower side and no connection visible on the upper side.
I had to design chamfered holes in order for the connections to be soldered to components, or the connections wouldn't be possible to acheive.

Chamfered holes and cut sections to make room for wires and soldered joints Second Design

Because I didn't like the idea to solder wires and melt the surrounding plastic (especially PLA), I thought about making wire connections just by friction, similarly like i did in my Solderless wire termination (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1381358).

That way I could also hide the connections inside the plastic part, so I drew them in the middle section. Also, that way the connections wouldn't be available to make any shorts or be unintentionally damaged.

The holes could be a bit smaller :) Final desing: top and bottom look the same (connections are hidden inside the plastic part) Making the STL

After the drawing was made I exported and saved it as STL.

Here placed using the Simplify3D software. Modifying G-code

Because I needed my printer to pause at a certain height, so that i could be able to insert the wire connection, I thought about using Cura software with it's plugin PauseAtZ (http://wiki.ultimaker.com/CuraPlugin:_Pauseatz).

Cura layer view: pausing and moving extruder to position X=5cm, Y=5cm from origin

Because I don't use Cura at all, I just wanted to see what this plugin code does to the G-code to make the printer pause.
I sliced the STL file, both in Cura and Siplify3D. I then compared the Simplify3D and Cura G-code as seen in the picture.

When examining the G-code and much help from the Reprap wiki page (http://reprap.org/wiki/G-code) and the G-code cheat sheet (https://thingiverse-production-new.s3.amazonaws.com/assets/87/b0/2c/f5/4c/CheatSheet.pdf), I was able to modify the Simplify3D code to my needs.

All of this could be also done if I would take a little bit of time to modify the original Python code of the plugin End result

At the end I was able to achieve what I was looking for - a printable PCB like circuit that WORKS!
So, my thought of making small printable PCBs for THT components and chips in DIL packages (see my Solderless wire termination: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1381358) is very much acheivable with a little bit of work and patience.

Of course it needs to be perfected, but the proof of concept has been acheived and I'm so very happy :)

Connection wires inserted while printing is paused

comments.text: Have you thought of making two halves and snap them together? I'm thinking either legos, snaps, or one side of a plastic buckle. That would solve the issue of needing to pause, and I think could be made small enough to not interfere with the circuits themselves.
comments.author: avatarofhope

comments.text: I haven't thought of that, but indeed it would be much simpler than having to pause the print and then hope it would work :)
comments.author: avatarofhope

comments.text: You are an artist!!. Before seeing your project, I thought of something. But yours is much better. Congratulations and thanks for sharing
comments.author: 4DR14N

comments.text: Thanks, you're welcome ;)
comments.author: 4DR14N

comments.text: Good work on this, it's an interesting idea and I could see this being something designed into a stand alone design program or plugin for an existing one. Possibly something like Fritzing or Eagle for PCB designing but have it output as an STL file or straight to GCODE (would make it easier to set the pause). Makes me wonder if the people who make those programs would consider adding this kind of capability. For the future I'd say to look into the socket type connections used in breadboards, I'm sure there's somewhere to source them and it could make the connections much simpler.
comments.author: LiGhTMaGiCk

comments.text:
Thank you very much for your comment and suggestion!
I was thinking about drawing in Eagle and then make an overlay of the PCB image to a SolidWorks part (but it was too time-consuming for a small project like this, which was meant just as a proof of concept).
As you said, it would be much easier if there would be an option to transform PCB designs from Eagle or similar program as follows:
1.) design PCB layout (ex. in Eagle)
2.) export PCB layout or make the "extrude-boss" (as in Solidworks) of the connections to make them a 3D object
3.) intersect a 3D object with the exported PCB (subtract the connections from a solid block to get the hollow lines for connection wires)
4.) make the gcode to pause printing before bridging and covering the connections
(5.) try to make a dual or more layered part ;) )

description.text:
This is a protective case for QRP labs Arduino shield kit (http://www.qrp-labs.com/uarduino.html).

The case provides access to the main connectors: USB, external power and RF-out.

Assembly is pretty straightforward. After having printed the bottom and the top part the Arduino Uno is tightened to the bottom part by 4 self-tapping screws (3mm x 6mm). Now the shield (including oscillator and LPF) is plugged into the Arduino. Finally the top part is put on and fastened to the bottom part by 4 self-tapping screws (3mm x 9mm).

If desirable the whole case can be attached to some surface (wall,...) and secured.

description.text: I design this small holder for the original DJI camera from the Phantom FC40 so it can be attached to the Walkera G-2D gimbal... I was originally going to use the original support and fix it to the gimbal, but I have a 3D printer so why just cut and glue when I can create a new one!!

Printer:

FolgerTech 2020

I used the M3 screws included on the gimbal kit to hold the bezel to the main body and SuperGlue (use the gel one) to attach the small lever to power on and off the camera and the supports that attach to the gimbal frame (you will require some cleaning of the holes before finish the assembly, to make it easy first set the support on the gimbal and then add some superglue and center the camera)... to remove the camera just use the holes on the back of the frame to push the camera out.

If you read online you will find that a lot of people complain about the gimbal jerking and the need to add screws, batteries or something else to increase the weight at the end of the arm... I don't know if Walkera has updated the firmware of the controller or what other factors are involved but my unit starts and moves fine without need to add extra, I power the gimbal with a small 7.4 Lipo 800mha that is on top of the gimbal controler.

title: Rawlings Synthetic Sparring Sword Wheel Pommel

description.text:
This is a rough copy of the standard wheel pommel used on Rawlings synthetic sparring swords. The measurements are approximate, and I haven't printed it, so you're on your own. But if all goes well, you should be able to glue an M8 nut into the hole at the bottom and screw it onto your sword. I included a tolerance of 0.1mm for the nut, which you can adjust by changing the variable.

I've added the variable captive_nut, which when set to 1 will give you a hexagonal hole in the base to hold a nut. If you set it to anything else, you'll just get a plain screw hole so you can screw directly into the plastic if you'd rather. You may need to drill out the hole a bit to fit. Additionally, the nut_tolerance variable is now just called tolerance, and it applies to the screw hole as well.

I've also added a facet variable ($fn) to make the pommel more round, but consider changing this to get interesting polygonal pommels. Note, however, that this will also affect the base, which will not quite line up with the grip if it's not round. I haven't decided if I should force it to be round.

Also this is literally the second SCAD object I've ever created, so sorry it's a bit messy. I'm still getting the hang of this.
